title: 110_s850
content: The "Scott Gardner Act" includes provisions for improved sharing of immigration information, state and local reporting of immigration data, DWI and immigration information in the National Criminal Information Center, state and local enforcement of Federal immigration laws, detention and deportation of aliens for driving while intoxicated, and Federal detention facilities. Definitions are provided in Section 2 of the Act. In this Act, DWI refers to driving while intoxicated. Federal immigration database includes databases related to immigration information. Immigration information is specified by the Secretary and includes illegal immigration details. LESC stands for Law Enforcement Support Center. The terms "LESC" refers to the Law Enforcement Support Center, "NCIC" refers to the National Crime Information Center of the FBI, and "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Homeland Security. Improved federal sharing of immigration information is addressed in Section 3. The Secretary will share immigration information with the Attorney General to improve the operation of federal immigration databases. Within 90 days of the Act's enactment, a report will be submitted to Congress on methods to enhance database performance and data entry efficiency. Proposals will focus on improving compatibility among federal immigration databases to streamline data entry and information exchange. The report will detail progress in eliminating data entry backlogs in databases and identify additional resources needed for this purpose. SEC. 4. STATE AND LOCAL REPORTING OF IMMIGRATION INFORMATION. State and local law enforcement agencies receiving Federal financial assistance must submit immigration and DWI information to the Secretary for entry into Federal databases. A report on additional resources needed for compliance must be submitted to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary promotes the use of the Law Enforcement Support Center by State and local agencies. State and local agencies are exempt from reporting immigration information on individuals who assist them in their duties. SEC. 5 mandates that DWI and immigration information be flagged in the NCIC database for law enforcement access. It requires officers to detain aliens with DWI and immigration violations until they can be transferred to Federal custody. SEC. 6 addresses State and local enforcement of Federal immigration laws. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require training reimbursement for State officers, eliminate a paragraph, and issue regulations within a year. The amendments made by subsection (a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act shall take effect on the earlier of the date regulations are issued or 1 year after the enactment of the Act. The amendment for payment of training costs will be effective on the first day of the first fiscal year after the Act's enactment. SEC. 7. DETENTION AND DEPORTATION OF ALIENS FOR DRIVING WHILE INTOXICATED. Amendment to Section 236 of the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding deportability for driving while intoxicated or under the influence of drugs. Amendment to Section 236 of the Immigration and Nationality Act adds a new subsection (e) for Driving While Intoxicated offenses. Law enforcement officers must use federal databases to determine if the individual apprehended is an alien unlawfully present in the United States. Officers covered under section 287(g) agreements may issue Federal detainers for such individuals. Section 287(g) allows officers to issue Federal detainers for aliens until conviction or transfer to Federal custody. The Secretary of Homeland Security will reimburse State and local agencies for alien transportation costs. If a database indicates an individual is an alien not unlawfully present, actions can be taken. If an alien is not unlawfully present in the United States and is convicted of driving while intoxicated, they shall be taken into custody, notified to the Secretary of Homeland Security, and held pending further action by the Secretary. Aliens convicted of driving while intoxicated, under the influence, or refusing a Breathalyzer test are deportable as per State law. Motor vehicle administrators must share information with the Secretary regarding such convictions or refusals. The amendment applies to violations occurring after the enactment of the Act. Aliens convicted of driving offenses are deportable under State law. Motor vehicle administrators must share this information with the Secretary and NCIC as required by law. Aliens convicted of driving offenses are deportable under State law. Motor vehicle administrators must share this information with the Secretary and NCIC as required by law. Federal detention facilities. The Secretary must report to Congress on the allocation formula for Federal detention facilities for aliens and propose temporary expansion of State and local jails for increased illegal alien detention. New detention facilities should be built in high concentration areas. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for necessary funds to carry out this section.
